Ottawa, May 11, 1918.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant enclosing report on the Temiskaming Indian School for the month of April and stating that there are ten children attending the school who are not members of the band.

In reply I have to ask you to be good enough to state whether these ten children you refer to are Indians or whites, and, if they are Indians, the band they belong to.

The Department is in receipt of a communication from Miss Delorme, the teacher of this school, in which she applies for this position for next year. She has been informed that the Department will be glad to have her take charge of this school again next year.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Renaud, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.
Sir,

In reply to the above I beg to say that the ten children attending the Temiskaming Indian School are Whites and half breeds who should attend the white school but for one reason or another prefer attending the Indian school.

I am sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 30, 1928.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 20th instant I have to ask you to be good enough to state whether there is a white school that the white and half-breed children who are at present attending the Temiskaming School could attend and, if so, why they do not go there.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Renaud, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.
August 20, 1918.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that Miss Delorme, teacher of the Temiskaming Indian school, who called at the Department a few days ago, stated that she would leave to take up her duties at the school again on Monday, the 2nd proximo, and would arrive in New Liskeard the next afternoon. I have to ask you to be good enough to make arrangements to have someone meet her there on Tuesday afternoon, September 3rd, next.

Your obedient servant,

J. B. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Renaud, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.
September 3, 1918.

Sir,

In reply to that portion of your letter of the 25th instant in regard to the education of your children I beg to say that the Department will have no objection to your children attending the Indian school at Temiskaming, but it is considered that you should pay a small amount for their education.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Mr. W. H. Thorneloe,
North Temiskaming P.O.,
Que.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from Mr. W. H. Thorneloe of North Temiskaming P.O., Que., in which he states that there is no school which his children can attend where they can learn English, with the exception of the Indian school.

Mr. Thorneloe is being informed that the Department will have no objection to his children attending the Indian school at Temiskaming, but that it is considered that he should pay a small amount for their education.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 22, 1916.

Sir,

Miss Delorme, teacher of the Temiskaming Indian School, called at the Department a few days ago and stated that the school had been closed by the doctor's orders on account of the epidemic of grippe.

This school should not remain closed any longer than is absolutely necessary and I have to ask you to be good enough to advise the Department when it may be reopened in plenty of time to notify Miss Delorme, so that there will not be any delay in her taking up her duties again.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Renaud, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.
November 21, 1918.

Sir,

In reference to official letter of the 22nd ultimo in regard to the closing of the Temiskaming Indian school on account of the epidemic of grippe on the reserve I have to ask you to be good enough to ascertain from the doctor when this school may be re-opened and advise the Department, so that Miss Delorme, the teacher, may be informed when she should take up her duties there again. You will be good enough to attend to this matter at once.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and secretary.

J. A. Renaud, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.
Ottawa, November 29, 1916.

Sir,

I beg to refer you to official letter of the 21st instant, in which you were asked to ascertain from the doctor when the Temiskaming Indian School may be re-opened and advise the Department.

Kindly let the Department know at once the date on which this school may be re-opened.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Renaud, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
NORTH TEMISKAMING, Que.
Sir,

In reply to the above I beg to say that almost all the Indians are moved in the bush for the winter. At present there are only two children that could attend school and that family expect to move away. I believe it is better to keep the school close until after the holidays and then I could ascertain of the number of children who could attend school during the winter and report to the Department.

I am sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, December 15, 1918.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, in which you state that you believe it is better to keep the Temiskaming School closed until after the holidays, as almost all the Indians are moved in the bush for the winter and at present there are only two children that could attend school and that family expect to move away.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of your remarks, Miss Delorme, the teacher, is being informed that this school will not be re-opened until after the Christmas holidays.

Kindly ascertain as soon as possible the number of children who could attend this school during the winter and advise the Department. As soon as you obtain this information you should at once notify the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Renaud, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.
Ottawa, January 3, 1919.

Sir,

I beg to refer you to official letter of the 18th ultimo in which you were asked to ascertain the number of children who could attend the Temiskaming Day School during the winter and advise the Department.

The Department would like to receive this information at once.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Remsud, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.
Sir,

In reply to the above I beg to say that until the 1st of April next all the Indians are in the bush and no children of school age will attend school. School should be closed until the first of April next.

I am sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, January 9, 1919.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that, as the Department has not received a reply to official letters of the 18th ultimo and the 3rd instant, in which you were asked to state the number of children who could attend the Temiskaming Day School during the winter, Miss Delorme, the teacher, who called at the Department today, has been instructed to reopen the school. She will leave for New Liskeard tomorrow night and will be ready to take up her duties at the school on Monday morning next.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Renouf, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.
January 14th/19

Sir,

I beg to acknowledged receipt of your letter of the 9th inst. no 152209/I which letter was received this day. On the 1st of January I have answered your letter of the 18th ultimo as follows.

### In reply to the above I beg to say that until the 1st of April next all the Indians are in the bush and no children of school age will attend school. School should be closed until the first of April next.

I have answered your letter of the 18th ultimo before I received your letter of the 3rd inst.

If Miss Delorme was to open the school on Monday January 13th I have not seen her yet nor heard that she was up.

am sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

I beg to advise the Department that Miss Delorme has arrived at North Temiskaming on the 14th Inst. in the evening, and has called at my office this day. She will open the school tomorrow afternoon. As stated in my letter of the 1st inst., there will be two children attending school. Miss Delorme has decided to keep the school open only in the afternoon of each day until more children are being able to attend.

Hoping that all will be satisfactory,

I am sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Dept| Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, March 25, 1919.

Sir,

It has been reported to the Department that there are some Indian children who are not members of the Temiskaming Band attending the school and that fees have been collected from them and that they have been charged for books which have been given them from the school supplies.

The Department would like to know whether this is the case and, if so, what has become of the money, as none has been sent to the Department. It is not the wish of the Department that Indian children should be charged fees, even if they are not members of the band, and any Indian child attending the school should be furnished free of charge with school books and supplies, as these are furnished by the Department for that purpose.

If you will refer to official letter of the 4th of September, last, you will see that Mr. Thorneloe, who applied for permission to send his children to this school, was informed that he would be allowed to do so on his paying a small fee for their education. No authority has ever been given to make a charge for Indian children.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Renaud, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.

Ottawa, March 27, 1919.

Madam,

It has been reported to the Department that there are some Indian children who are not members of the Temiskaming Band attending the school and that fees have been collected from them and that they have been charged for books which have been given them from the school supplies.

I have to ask you to be good enough to state if this is the case and, if so, who has collected the money and what has become of it.

It is not the wish of the Department that Indian children should be charged fees, even if they are not members of the band, and any Indian child attending the school should be furnished free of charge with school books and supplies, as these are furnished by the Department for that purpose. If any white children are attending the school, a fee should be charged for them.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Teacher,
Temiskaming Indian School,
North Temiskaming, Que.

I, Margaret Delorme, engage to teach school in District Temiskaming, of the Municipality of Nedelie for ten months commencing the fourth of September, 1919. I further agree to do my best to carry out all the regulations for the management of the school.

Sir,

A communication has been received from Miss Margaret Delorme, teacher of the Temiskaming Indian school, in which she applies for this position for next year.

Miss Delorme has been informed that the Department will be glad to have her take charge of this school again next year.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 22, 1919.

Indian,

I beg to inform you that it has been decided, as requested by you while you were in the Department on the 19th instant, to allow the annual holidays at the Temiskaming Indian Day School to be taken during the months of January and February, next, and to keep the school open during the following July and August. You will be good enough to inform the Parish Priest at Temiskaming of this change being made.

It is hoped that you will be ready to re-open the school on or about the first of March, next.

Your obedient servant,

J.B. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Miss Margaret Delorme,
Luskville,
Que.

Jan 14-1920
L.D. McLean Asst Deputy and Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Canada

Sir:

I have been requested by the Chief
J.G. McBride to apply for the position of school
teacher, for the coming term Sept. 1920.

I am a graduate of the Moors Training Class,
of Moors, New York County of
Wellington, graduated in the year nineteen
hundred and eleven. Taught one year in
Moors, N.Y., and coming over to spend
summer with relations, stayed, and
taught one year in White River Ontario.
The following year I got married, since
I have often been asked by the Indians
to try and obtain the position of teacher.
Some time ago I wrote to the State
Department of New York to renew my
certificate. I am forwarding you the
answer, also certificate, which is renew-
able should I wish to teach in New York
State.
I live half a mile from the school and have been staying here since I have been married, six years ago. I did not try for the place before I felt that I could safely undertake the position and make a success of it.

Should you wish for references the teachers I moved Training Cass Moore N.Y. and the school secretary Joseph Shields White River Ontario, would gladly furnish them to you.

Hoping to receive a favorable reply and please understand that I am ready to furnish you with any informations concerning my training and qualifications in regards to teaching the Indian School.

Very Truly,

Drew LaFrance Porcher
North Simiskaming
Pontiac Co. P.Q.
Ottawa, January 20, 1920.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant applying for a position as teacher upon the re-opening of the schools after the summer holidays, or about September 1st, 1920, and enclosing a certificate of your qualifications from the State of New York.

In reply I beg to say that, with regard to the school at Temiskaming, to which it is presumed you refer, the Department has no knowledge at the present time that there will be a vacancy. Miss Delorme, who is at present teaching, has given no intimation that it is her intention to give up her duties. If, however, she should do so your application will receive consideration.

The Department is unable to tell you of what vacancies there may be for teachers in any of its Indian schools next September. It might be well for you to again make application about the first of July, next, when the Department will have knowledge of any vacancies that will occur and where new teachers will be required after the summer holidays.

The certificate which you forwarded is being returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Mrs. Henri LeFrance Provencher,
North Temiskaming,
Pontiac Co., Que.
We had to close school our
school up here on account of the "flu"
The teachers had an attendance of 15 pupils
since the school reopened the second day
of February. All the pupils are sick
with the "flu" so the school closed
Monday noon the twenty-third. She does
not know what to do as we have no
agent.

So kindly answer at once and let
her know what to do or if she should
go home for awhile. I do not think
that we will be able to get her in
for a while. We will have Miss Delorme
trail until we hear from you. We
would like her to be our teacher again
for we feel sorry for the girl. We
are sure it is not adequate for her.
Your obedient servant

John George M. Bridge
Chief
Ottawa, February 27, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, in which you state that the Temiskaming School has been closed on account of the influenza and ask whether the teacher should go home, as you do not think the school can be re-opened for a while.

In reply I beg to say that it is considered that the teacher should remain on the reserve, as, no doubt, the worst of the epidemic of influenza there will soon be over and she will be able to re-open the school. While the school is closed she might be able to help in the homes of some of the Indians who are sick.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Chief John George McBride,
North Temiskaming,
Que.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, March 30, 1920.

Sir,

On the occasion of your visit to Temiskaming I have to request that you will visit the Indian day school, which is taught by Miss Margaret Delorme, and inspect the work she is doing in the class-room.

Miss Delorme has applied for re-appointment during the next school year, beginning September 1st, 1920, and the Department will be pleased if you will advise as to whether you consider she should be retained as teacher of this school. The Department will be pleased if you will furnish a full report regarding the work done at this school.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

O. O. Parker, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, March 30, 1920.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, in which you offer your services as teacher of the Temiskaming Indian Day School for the next school year, beginning September 1st, 1920.

In reply I beg to say that an officer of the Department will visit Temiskaming in the near future, and you will be informed later regarding your request to be engaged for another year.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Miss Margaret Delorme,
Teacher,
Temiskaming Indian Day School,
North Temiskaming, Que.
Sir,

The school-teacher Miss M. Delemme has requested me to make inquiries concerning pupils not belonging to the band who are attending her school, and also for others who wish to do so.

As there is no other school teaching the English language but the Temiskaming School the parents of these children are anxious to have their children attend it.

Please advise me if the Department is willing to allow these children to attend this school and if so what charges are to be made, also if ### children with Indian blood are to charged for books.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

N. A. McDonald,
Acting Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

Miss M. Delorme teacher of Temiskaming day School requests that she be allowed to teach Saturdays for the remainder of school term in order that she may close school when the usual number of school days have been taught. Please advise if the Department approves of this.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. A. Mc Donald,
Act'g Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 19, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant requesting to be informed on behalf of the teacher of the Temiskaming Indian Day School whether white children should be permitted to attend in the classroom with the Indian children and stating that there are a number of such children whose parents are anxious to have them taught English.

In reply I beg to say that, provided these children will not interfere with the instruction being given the Indian children and that there is accommodation for them and the teacher will undertake the work, they may be permitted to attend. A fee at the rate of $1.00 per month for each child should be collected by you from the parents and forwarded to the Department. Books and stationery will be provided for the Indian children only. The parents of the white children who attend should provide the necessary school books and supplies for their own children.

With reference to the teacher's request mentioned in your letter of the 12th instant, to be permitted to teach on Saturdays for the remainder of the school term, in order that she may close school when the full number of school days have been taught, I beg to say that the Department cannot consent to this arrangement. It would not be fair to the children to compel them to attend school on Saturdays. The teacher should keep the school open during the regular hours only. You will be good enough to inform her accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

D. A. McDonald, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.
Sir:

Enclosed please find school report for the Temiskaming day school which I trust will be found in order.

I beg also to be allowed to make a few recommendations regarding the conducting of this school which at the present time is not very satisfactory.

I would suggest that the two months vacation be given in the winter instead of the summer say from the 21st of December till the first of February, and the school run continuously during the summer. A large number of the Indians of this district leave the village every fall and go into the bush for the winter, taking their families with them. This deprives the children of their education for that period and, by the time they get good and well started to school in the spring the school closes for the summer vacation and, after the school reopens they take another short course and then away for the winter.

By running the school continuously during the summer months the children would have a larger percentage of schooldays in the year and would have a much better opportunity of getting an education. There is quite a few pupils attending the school at present but they are mostly all white peoples children residing in close proximity to
the school.

I would also recommend that some form of compulsory attendance be enforced as the Indians here are very lax in sending their children to school.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Sir,

Ottawa, December 6, 1920.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo enclosing your report on the Temiskaming Indian Day School for the month of November, last.

Regarding your recommendation that this school be closed during the months of January and February for the annual vacation and conducted during the summer months when the Indians are back on the reserve I beg to say that the Department will approve of this being done. You may inform Miss Delorme, the teacher, that she is to take holidays during the above two months and be prepared to re-open the school on the first of March, next, and teach continuously during the summer.

Regarding the white children who attend I beg to say that the Department consented to their doing so, provided they do not interfere with the instruction being given the Indian children and that there is accommodation for them and also that the teacher would undertake the work. A fee at the rate of $1.00 per month for each child was to be collected from the parents and forwarded to the Department. Books and stationery are only provided for the Indian children and the parents of the white children who attend are expected to provide the necessary school books and supplies for their own children. I should be pleased to hear whether any fees have been collected from the white parents by the late agent, the teacher or yourself and, if so, if you are aware what disposal was made of the money so collected.

The question of enforcing the regulations regarding compulsory attendance will receive consideration when the school re-opens after the first of March, next, provided the Indian parents do not see that their children attend regularly.

Your obedient servant,

William H. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Indian Agents Office,
North Temiskaming,
Que.

Dec. 9th, 1920

Sir:

In reply to your letter No. 35-1-1 of the 6th inst., I beg to say that the instructions re the closing of the Indian School will be followed.

Regarding the fees to be collected from the white children I may say that I have not as yet collected any myself, and I will inquire of Mr. McDonald the first time I see Him.

I think that Miss Delorme collected some fees during the summer and I will inquire of her what disposition she made of them.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Sir:

At a council meeting of the Temiskaming Band held on the 27th inst., the matter of the way in which the Temiskaming day school is conducted was discussed at some length.

There was 36 members present and 32 out of the 36 recommended a change of school teachers, as they claim the present teacher Miss Delarme is not giving the attention she should do to her duties, and they ask me to write to the Department and get them a new teacher.

It is reported to me that the teacher does not arrive at the school punctual, as she gets there any time between 9 and 10 o'clock in the forenoon, and since I have held the office of Agent the school has been closed at 3 o'clock every afternoon, and quite a few days the school teacher has not presented herself at the school house at all the children having had to return home.

It is hard to learn children to be punctual unless they are given an example by the teacher, and I believe it is required by the Department that the school be open from 9 a.m. till 4 p.m.

I would also like to know if the parish priest has anything to do with the affairs of the Indian School.

I advised the teacher of the Department's decision to close the school for the 2 months vacation in January & February on condition that the school be open during July and August, as per Letter No. 35-1-1 of the 6th ed. December but she informs me that she would not teach these two months.

Under the circumstances I would recommend that Miss Delarme be transferred to some other agency or that she be given to understand that the school hours are from 9 a.m. till 4 p.m. and every day as I would like to see the school brought to a higher state of efficiency.

There is also some French taught in the school which the Indians do not want as the majority of the scholars cannot read or write English yet.

I regret to have to report this matter as I believe this state of affairs has been brought about by the indifference of the Agent in regard to the school. Referring to the disposition made of the fees collected from the white children, I took the matter up with Miss Delarme who promised to give me an account of the same at the end of the term, but she left without doing so.

Your obedient servant,

William Lewis
Indian Agent

J.D. McLean Esq.
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Ottawa, January 6, 1921.

Madam,

The Department is informed that, at a council meeting of the Temiskaming Band, the matter of the way in which you conduct the Temiskaming Indian Day School was discussed. The Indians claim that you do not give the attention you should to your duties and request that the services of a new teacher be engaged. They state that you do not open the school punctually, arriving at the school in the morning any time between nine and ten o'clock, also that the school was closed at three o'clock every afternoon and that quite a few times you did not appear at the school-house at all and the children had to return home.

The Indians seem dissatisfied with your work and the attention you have been giving to your duties. It would, therefore, appear in the best interests of all concerned that you tender your resignation, as it will not be possible for you to render good services in future when it would appear that you have not the confidence of the Indian parents. I shall be pleased to hear from you at an early date in the matter.

Authority was granted last spring to permit the attendance of white children on payment of a fee at the rate of $1.00 per month for each child. It is understood that a portion of these fees were collected by you and I shall also be pleased to hear from you as to what disposition you made of the fees you collected.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Miss Margaret Delorme,
Luskville,
Que.

Ottawa, January 6, 1921.

In reply to official letter No.35-1-1 of the 3rd inst., regarding the appointment of a second teacher at the Temiskaming Indian Day School for the summer months, I beg to say that at present there is accommodation for 48 scholars in this school. MEMORANDUM

Dr. McGill.

For some time, consideration has been given to a change in the teaching services in the Indian day school on Temiskaming Reserve, No. 19, located at the head of Lake Temiskaming, in the Province of Quebec. At the present time this school is taught by a lay teacher, Miss Catherine Honan, who has been in our employ for a considerable time. It is considered that it would be in the interests of the work to place the teaching services under the control of the Grey Nuns, who have offered to provide a Reverend Sister having the necessary qualifications. There is an enrolment of 45 children, and the average attendance during the last fiscal year was 30.

Miss Honan, who is an elderly woman, is popular with the Indians, as she is in the habit of presenting gifts to the children. The Agent states that she has been advising the Indians they are not receiving proper treatment in the way of relief supplies and also in other matters. Both the local parish priest and Indian Agent recommend that the services of Miss Honan be dispensed with and that arrangements be made with the Grey Nuns to supply a qualified teacher.

The Chief of the Band visited the Department yesterday and protested against any change being made, as he states the Band are in favour of retaining Miss Honan's services. The Agent states that the Indians are influenced by the gifts which their children receive from the teacher, and that her advice to the Indians is undermining his influence.

The question of engaging the services of a Sister of the Grey Nuns has been deferred for two years, owing to the fact that the Order did not have proper living accommodation, but arrangements are now complete for the housing of the Order in Temiskaming. On reserves where we employ Nuns as teachers, there has been marked improvement in the work in the school, in the homes and in the cleanliness and betterment of the Indians. I have taken this matter up with the Agent, and I am of opinion that a change should be made in the teaching services and that the Order of the Grey Nuns should be requested to supply a qualified teacher for the coming school year, beginning September first, next, and should be pleased to have your instructions in the matter.

Sir,

Referring to official letter No. 35-1-X informing me that the Department has decided not to make any change in the services at the Temiskaming Indian Day School for the coming year, I beg to say that this confirms the report brought here by the chief last week.

After the conversation I had with the Department on this subject and official letter No. 35-1-X of May 27th, I am left with the impression that the facts have not been made clear to the Department, and I feel it is my duty to try and make things as clear as possible to the Department.

I wish to say a word about the Chief's visit to Ottawa. The last time I visited the Department, I mentioned the fact that the Chief was anxious to go to Ottawa to discuss certain matters with the Department, and asked how it could be done, so that his expenses would be paid. I thought it would be necessary to have a meeting of the band to approve of this trip, or to delegate him to go to Ottawa. I was told by the Department that the Chief was not needed in Ottawa. Furthermore, I was told that not long before the Chief had been returned, and had to pay his own expenses, because he had made a trip to Ottawa without authority.

Naturally, I brought this news to the band, who had no reason to believe that I would make a false report. I have never tried by any means to stop the Chief from going to Ottawa, and I had no reason to do so.

When Dr. Wall visited my agency, he made a report against Chief Wabie because he had criticised the vaccination of Indians. Dr. Wall offered to report him to the Deputy Minister if he was causing any trouble but I excused the Chief, whom I thought did not know the extent of his criticism.

Later on, the Chief had some trouble with Indians, and came and handed me his resignation. I encouraged the Chief, and told him to do his best and not mind the talking of others, and to remain chief of the band. I believe this proves that I have always treated the chief with kindness, and that I have nothing against him.
On the other hand, I very often had to soothe his nerves, for he is very nervous and excitable. He wants to rush every sick Indian to the hospital. Many times I have heard the Indians say, the Chief is going to take so-and-so to the hospital, in spite of the agent or the doctor.

On one of these occasions, Dr. Beausejour was treating a young Indian for Pneumonia. The Indians came running to me, saying this young man was dying, and that the Chief was going to send him to the hospital if I did not.

I found it necessary to call Dr. Beausejour, and have him visit this young man. To his surprise, he found the patient resting comfortably. And neither he nor his father had thought of the hospital.

Naturally, the attitude of the Chief leads me to believe, that possibly, he has exaggerated the feelings of the Indians; as regards a Rev. Sister teaching.

There may be one or two exceptions, one of these is George Polson, the son of a white man. His mother brought him to the reserve, later marrying a white woman, so that his son was accepted by the band. Lately, some Indians reported him to the department, even his father-in-law who has been chief of the band was telling me that by rights he should not be a member.

There would be more joy if this man was put out of the band, than if the teacher was nominated. This man is pretty wicked, and among others the Chief fears him very much.

Miss Honan whose principal occupation has been to keep the good favors of the Indians, thought he was a good member to be looked after, and is treating him very well. She bought a cow for him, and placed his little girl in a convent. So that, in working for the teacher, he is working for himself. I see no other that would try and cause trouble.

Miss Honan was telling me, that if the Department engaged a Nun, the Indians would not send their children to school. This pretention is ridiculous and at the same time, a challenge to the Department.

We have on this reserve, about one hundred Indians who are getting relief at the rate of $6,000.00 at least, a year. Not one family has been able to live without assistance. Would it not be ridiculous for these Indians to talk about mutiny. I am sure they do not think of that, although it would please the teacher, and everything would go on just as well without Miss Honan here.

Miss Honan has in her mind that the Indians should be their own boss, and always have the right to choose their own teacher. She wants the Indians
to be children when it is a question of work, or relief, but men when it comes to fighting her case. Miss Honan told the Priest and myself, that it was not a question of the position or the money, but she is fighting for the principal, that, the Indians have the right to choose their own teacher. I answered that I had been Indian Agent for eight years, and that the Department had never asked me to consult the band for the nomination of the teacher, but had always asked for a recommendation from the Parish Priest, or Missionary. I was not asked this time either, but thought it would be more charitable to see Miss Honan. Seeing that she does not need the position or the money, and that she has to make a false declaration every time she endorses her superannuation check, as she has to certify that she has not been teaching since receiving her pension.

I am under the impression that she is exposing herself to some trouble.

As I stated before, when in Ottawa, I mentioned the fact that the Chief wished to go to Ottawa, and it was not approved by the Department. I wish to add, that not very long before this trip, at a meeting of the Temiskaming Band, he urged the Indians to send him to Ottawa to discuss certain matters with the Department. But not one showed himself in favor of his going. So that his trip was made without any authority whatever. And it was a surprise to many, when on his return he mentioned the fact that his expenses had been paid. As far as the teacher is concerned it would only been a matter of a few hours to call a meeting of the band to approve of his trip if they were in favor of it.

As the Rev. Father Lagrevel informed me he would visit the Department shortly, I thought I had better wait before announcing the decision of the Department to Miss Honan.

A.F. MacKenzie Esq.
Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

To the Secretary

Ottawa Ont.

Having been informed that some white people are trying to have a grey nun engaged as teacher for next year I am writing to advise you that all members of the band are opposed to it, as we had nuns once, and our children got nothing but abuse from them. They compelled poor half-clad Indian children to attend church a mile away from their homes on days that a dog shouldn't be put out, and the children came home often with marks on them from blows given by the teacher. And if there will be a change in a teacher we would like very much to get a normal trained teacher of mature years or one with a widowed mother who could live with her. I would appreciate it very much if the answer to this letter be sent to me, as so far I have never seen an answer to a letter of mine.

Dear Sir:

Re: Timiskaming Agency

I beg to submit the following report of inspection made on June 7th, 1938, of the above agency.

The Indian school was also inspected. The premises are very clean and attractive, the children look bright, healthy, and are neatly dressed. They all have individual drinking cups. Sister St John, their teacher, deserves credit for her good work and her efficiency.

Twenty-five children are registered. The average attendance is twenty, and we found present on our visit, fifteen boys and seven girls.

Jude Thibault,

Quarterly Report ending March, 1945, on Temiskaming Agency

Welfare:

A new school should be built on the reserve at Notre-Dame-du-Nord, and also one at Long Point.

R. Lamothe,
Indian Agent.
The old school house will need replacing in a very near future, however it should be built on a more central place a short distance south of the present site. Sister Jean, of the Grey Nuns, is doing real good work with the Indians, and has had also successful results with Indian women, whom she has been receiving on Saturdays, training them in sewing, remodelling old clothing. Such missionary work is doing a lot of good and brings about better understanding of what the Department is doing for the Indians. Last year, a sewing machine was sent there, and I was very pleased upon my visit to see young girls work made on the machine.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Agent's Report for the three months ending December 31, 1945.

Education:

I would advocate that a summer school be opened for the Indians from Sand Point, have a teacher not only able to teach the three R's but teach them cleanliness in themselves and in their homes. The school in Notre Dame du Nord is so cold that arrangements should be made to build a new one.

Robert Lamethe
Indian Agent.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, requesting an advance of $25.00 on your June quarter salary as teacher of the Temiskaming Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that a cheque for the above amount will be sent you.

In connection with these advances I beg to inform you that it is not the rule of the Department to make advances on salary to the teachers in its Indian day schools, as the Auditor General objects to these advances being made each quarter. Your salary, in future, can only be paid quarterly upon receipt of returns of attendance.

You should endeavour to arrange your financial affairs so that it will not be necessary to ask for these advances as such requests cannot in future be complied with.

Your obedient servant

J.D. McLean
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Miss Margaret Delorme,
Teacher,
Indian Day School,
North Temiskaming,
QUE.

North Temiskaming,
March 21st 1904.

Hon. Supt-General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

We no longer have any school or a master to teach. To my knowledge, Mr. McCarragher was quite faithful in conducting the class and no serious complaint had been made against him. Nevertheless, since his departure complaints have been made and reasons have been alleged why the parents did not send their children to school. It is certain that the school was poorly attended out of from 40 to 50 children of school age one could hardly find more than 10 or 15 who went there. Our Indians, who had this school conducted by the sisters some years ago, and who remember and still see the good, that they derived from them desire to have the sisters again and
and, with this object, they have earnestly asked your honour the favour of using part of the money that they have on deposit in Ottawa, to build a house for these men, who, at the same time, would attend to their sick and would be able, for that purpose, to keep two or three beds at their disposal. This would be by far the best use the Indians could make of their money for the future of their children.

(Sgd) Isidore Evans O.M.S.
Missionary
OTTAWA, 2nd May, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Rev. Father Ewaim, missionary at North Temiscamingue, asks that permission be given the Indians to use a portion of their funds to build a house for the accommodation of the nuns who are to take charge of their school, and which would also furnish accommodation for a certain number of sick Indians.

The question of building a hospital at N. Temiscamingue was before the Department last when year, when it was decided that it could not see its way clear to sanction the necessary expenditure. The nuns are now to be placed in charge of the school and they want a home.

The Temiscamingue Indians have about $14,000.00 to their credit and it would take about $1,000.00 to put up a suitable building. A Resolution for this purpose was passed by the Band in April 1903 and the same reasons for not giving it now hold good as were in force then.

Memo. for the Deputy Minister: -

In respect to a house for School Teacher, North Temiscamingue Reserve: -

The Band has passed a resolution to give a grant of $1000.00 to the Society of the Good Shepherd for the erection of a building on the reserve to accommodate nuns. Two of these are attending to the household affairs of the Church, one is expected to come in as teacher for the reserve and one as a nurse for the Indians and adjoining settlers. The Band is very desirous of making this grant.

The Chief after conversation with yourself is inclined to think that the Band would recognize that for it as a municipal organization to make a grant in this way might be injudicious.

But a residence for a teacher is an urgent necessity and the Chief submits that the Band should put up a teacher's residence to be owned by itself, which, so far as it conveniently can, may be used by the nun who is going to assume the duties of school teacher and any associates of hers that may choose to occupy it with her.

He considers, however, that it should be clearly understood that this house is for the purposes of a school teacher and for any such school teacher as may from time to time be appointed.

He feels sure of the concurrence of the Band in this project.

To the Superintendent of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

Mr. John King chief of the Indians of North Temiscamingue Reserve tells me that at the request of the Indians of this Reserve you have consented to build a convent for the nuns teaching Indian children here and that you ask me to draw a plan for this projected convent. Therefore, at the request of the chief, send you, here enclosed, a combined plan of a school and convent. The actual school is an old building which need to be removed besides having the inconvenience of being situated on low land, far away from the projected convent, which must necessarily be built close to the church and would be in a more central place for all Indian children if it was built near the church. For all these reasons I thought it was better to include the school in the convent building.

You will see also that I have provided for two class rooms in the convent. The nuns tell me that
just now the daily average attendance at the school is from 35 to 40 children and that they expect to have an average attendance of 50 children in the spring when all the Indians will be back from the bush. You understand that 50 children in one class is rather too much for one class. The number of children might yet increase later on.

Moreover we are going to organize a School Municipality here for white people and, if possible, would like to unite with Indian Department to have only one school for white and Indian children which would be far cheaper and better for both parties.

I wish therefore to know if the Department could not grant us a certain return of money, and with that money and money voted by the school Municipality of North Temiscamingue or subscription made amongst white people we would build the school and conduct according to the included plan or any plan suggested by the Department; at the conditions however that if later on the school was not found satisfactory to Indians and that Indians for good reason were willing to have a separate school for themselves we would guarantee to refund all the money voted by the Indian Department for the school and cement which would remain then the property of the School Municipality of North Temiscamingue.
Thus the money granted by the Department would be well secured and we could have a first class school which would be all at the advantage of young Indian children who can but gain to be in contact with white children. Another advantage would be to have two classes in the same school which would permit to divide children according to their capacities and give them consequently a better chance to make good progress.

I hope therefore that these propositions will be acceptable to the Department so much the more as Indians are in favor of it.

I am just here mentioning an idea which might be modified more or less later on. I would like to know what are the intentions of the Department regarding this important matter. A thing that is certain is that Indians are well satisfied with the nuns and that since the nuns are in charge of the school the children have attended the school most regularly and have made greater progress than ever since the school exist here.

It is urgently desired that this state of affairs continue and for that we must provide a home for the teaching nuns.

Hoping that you will take this affair into serious consideration and that I will have the pleasure to hear soon from you.

I remain Your most sincerely,

A. Laniel (M.I. Parish Priest of North Temiskaming)

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Bourbonnais, M.P., writes on behalf of the settlers of North Temiscamingue who are anxious to have a combined school for Indian and white children to be placed under the charge of the nuns who are now teaching there. If the Department approves of this scheme, it would be necessary to have new school quarters as the present building, which is only 18 by 20 ft., is too small to accommodate all the Indian children who should attend. The return for Sept. quarter shows an enrollment of 49 children with an average attendance of 38, which must have overtaxed the seating capacity of the school. The proposition submitted by Mr Bourbonnais calls for a contribution of $2000.00 from the Temiscamingue Band, which is double the amount asked by the priest for this purpose. The Band voted $1000.00 for a suitable dwelling for their teacher and this is quite as much as their funds will stand. They have not voted this money as a contribution to a nunnery, or a combined schoolhouse and residence for the nuns, and if such a building is put up, the present schoolhouse will be left on their hands.

The $300.00 already contributed by the Government towards the salary of a teacher should be sufficient if there was a combined school as the white settlers should make up the difference. As a usual
thing the Indians are not in favor of having their children educated at white schools or in conjunction with whites, and they have not so far intimated their desire to do so in this case. I see no objection to the children being educated together, but a joint ownership of the building would likely cause trouble, as the Indians would contribute most of the money and have the least to say in its management.

As the matter now stands, the proposition before the Department is for the Indians to take $1000.00 from their capital, which is only about $13,000.00 for the erection of a teacher's residence. The Department votes $300.00 for a salary and the Indians pay for the maintenance of the school. It seems to me that this proposition is more in the interests of the Church and the white settlers than the Indians.

Ottawa, January 16, 1908.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

I have to report that on Tuesday last I made an inspection of the new Indian Day school recently erected at North Temiscamingue Indian Reserve for the Band there.

The building is of frame erected according to plan and specification. The work is well done and the material supplied fair with a few exceptions.

The drop siding is rather rough and knotty some which are dead and showing through the paint. The interior has been oiled one coat instead of being painted three coats of lead and oil as specified. It will be necessary to give the interior walls two additional coats of oil to satisfactorily complete and this should be done during the Easter holidays to prevent interference with the school which is now open.

A small portable platform for teachers' use has been put in instead of the stationary one extending entirely across the room as shown on the plan, as the teacher preferred the smaller one.

The porch entrance, and steps leading thereto, are of rough planking instead of matched flooring which, however, answers the purpose equally as well and the difference in cost is immaterial.

The W.Cs. erected in rear of the school are substantially built and the price charged is reasonable. The school lot should be fenced also a division fence put up dividing the ward so as to separate the entrance to W.Cs. as both are built under one roof, the doors being within
a few feet of each other without any screen or divided approach to the entrance.

The school required six additional seats, five ordinary and one back seat only, one dozen ink wells for the desks now in use and a globe for illustrating the maps, etc.

The Agent informed me that the necessary papers assigning the occupants rights and improvements made on the school site to the Department had been signed and forwarded some months ago and as these have apparently miscarried other papers will be executed if sent to the Agent.

I would recommend that the Contractor be paid the amount of his contract and extra for the W.Cs., less one hundred dollars to be retained until the completion of the oiling of interior walls and ceilings, when the balance should be paid him.

Architect.

July 15, 1890

Sir,

I have been unable to
read your letter of
the last, enclosing
a report on the
Temiscamingue Indian
school for the month
June last; and in
reference to your
remark that the
house should be
in a more convenient
place, I have begged
that you will report
on the proposed rebuild
of the school house state
the probable cost of the
same and the details.
Tenders were called for, and the lowest - $950 - accepted.

The building itself has actually been constructed; but, since the contract was let, water closets have had to be built, at a cost of $40 extra; a fence will have to be placed around the school lot, another one is required to separate the playgrounds for boys and for girls to the N.C.; some additional seats, a desk and a globe, have been found necessary, and there may be some other small contingencies. These items will bring the amount required up to the $1100 asked for in accompanying memo. to Council.

The old school-house was in bad shape, was too small for the number of school children on the reserve and was awkwardly situated at one side of the reserve; whereas the new building is larger and is situated in the center of the settled portion of the reserve. The intention is to dispose of the old building.

There are about 48 school children (26 boys & 16 girls) on the reserve.

31 Jan., '08.
Nord Temiskaming, Que., Feb. 3

J.E. McLean,
Secy. of Engine Affairs, Ottawa.

Robert King anxiously waiting school contract cheque.

Thos. Murray

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, in which you report that at a recent meeting of the Temiscamingue Band a resolution was passed to the effect that the inside of the Indian school house be painted during the summer vacation; and in reply I beg to say that it is observed that while you state that the cost of the work will be about $35.00, you have failed to make a recommendation in the matter. It is desired that you will report at once stating whether you consider it necessary to have the proposed work done. I may say that the funds at the credit of the band are not sufficient to admit of the expenditure in question being charged to them. If the work is done, the cost will have to be charged to a Parliamentary appropriation.

Your obedient servant,

D. McLean

Sir,

I beg to recommend that in the interests of economy, that it would be advisable to give the Indian schoolhouse a coat of paint this spring.

It has been a number of years since the schoolhouse was painted last, and the woodwork is now commencing to show signs of deterioration. If the exterior only is painted it would cost, together with the little repairs that are needed to the woodwork, about $50.00. If the interior is painted as well it would cost around $80.00 or $95.00, but tenders could be called from the members of the band, and maybe it could be done cheaper. As the surface to be covered is quite a size, the cost of the paint would be the biggest item.

There also needs to be provided 6 new window blinds, as these in use have done service since the schoolhouse was erected, and are now in a dilapidated condition.

Sir:

I beg to enclose voucher in favor of Alphonse Robert, of North Temiskaming, Que., for material purchased to paint the interior and exterior of the Temiskaming Indian day school-house, also abstract of tenders called for same. Sir—

These expenses were incurred in small repairs to the Temiskaming Indian school-house, and teacher's residence. I also had to get a box stove put up in the teacher's house, for which purpose I purchased a tee pipe, and the stove I used is the one that was in the jail house.

I beg to inform the Department that

Doctor Wall (during his official visit to North Temiskaming) found defective eyesight common among the pupils of the Indian school and recommended as a remedy that a slate blackboard be substituted for a worn out hyloplate now in use. Also that the windows be re-modelled so as to allow ventilation at the top and bottom as he attributed certain constitutional ailments prevalent among the pupils to lack of proper ventilation. The size of the blackboard in use is 3 ft. by 8 ft.

Ottawa, August 21, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, informing the Department that Dr. Wall recommends, as a remedy to prevent defective eyesight among the pupils, that slate blackboards be substituted for the one at present in use, also that the windows be remodelled to provide ventilation.

In reply I beg to say that we do not supply slate blackboards to Indian day schools. We are, however, placing an order with the Government Stationery Office here to forward to the teacher's address a Lithoplate blackboard, 5' x 3'. When this arrives, you should arrange to set it up in the classroom in the place of the present worn out Hyloplate board.

I shall be pleased to hear further as to what you would recommend be done in the remodelling of the windows in order that they will provide ventilation at both the top and bottom. You should give the approximate cost of any work in having these windows remodelled. When we have this information, consideration will then be given to authorizing you to have the work carried out.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I inspected the North Temiskaming agency on the 7th-9th instant and beg to submit the following report.

I visited the Timiskaming Day School and found conditions very satisfactory. The average attendance is 30 with 40 pupils on the roll. The teacher has excellent discipline in the classroom. The pupils look robust and tidy. They are given Cod Liver Oil daily during the winter months and have all been vaccinated. The agent reports that very good progress is being made by the pupils at this school.

The school buildings are in good repair with the exception of the closets. The boys' and girls' closets are in the same small building, separated only by a single board partition. I found the boys' side in a filthy unsanitary condition, a menace to health. There should be a new closet built with two seats and placed on another location at some distance from the other for the girls' use. I recommend that this be done. The present arrangement is not good.

Thos. McGookin.
Inspector.
Ottawa, November 28, 1932.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his recent visit to the Temiskaming Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the boys' and girls' closets. He states these closets are in the same building, separated only by a single board petition, and that the boys' side is in a filthy, unsanitary condition.

If weather conditions permit, you should have these toilets cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition. You should have this work carried out as soon as possible, forwarding an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost, which should be kept as low as possible. It may be possible for you to arrange to have Indians on the relief list do this work without expense to the Department.

The Inspector has recommended that two separate toilets be built next Spring, on another site, one for the boys and one for the girls. You might draw this matter to the attention of the Department early next Spring, stating the type of toilet you would recommend be erected and the approximate cost of the material and labour. We will have no funds this year to build new toilets.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Je vous félicite également de l'amélioration sanitaire que vous avez pu obtenir à cette école, et il est à souhaiter que les déficiences existant actuellement disparaissent avec le temps, principalement la mauvaise eau que boivent les enfants.

Veuillez bien me croire,

Votre tout dévoué,

Officier médical.

Sir-

I beg to enclose a report of Dr. Albini Jeannotte who made the inspection of the Temiskaming Indian Day School. As it appears on the report, all the children have been vaccinated.

According to this report, the water used for the school is bad. I do not understand this because it is a new well and it is clear sand water. However, I will inquire from Dr. Jeannotte to find out what is the trouble and will report later, that is before the opening of the school in Sept.

Your obedient servant

A.F. MacKenzie Esq.
Secretary

Ottawa.

Sir-

I beg to inform the Department that it has been the custom of the Indians of the Temiskaming band to give a dance in the school house every time there is an election for a chief.

I mentioned this fact to the late Mr. Ferrier once when in Ottawa and he told me that the Department was opposed to any dances taking place in the school house.

As an election is to take place the last day of this month, I would be pleased to be advised by the Department on this subject.

The parish priest is opposed to these dances by the Indians and I do not believe they bring much good to them.

Your obedient servant

A.F. MacKenzie Esq.
Secretary.
Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Sir-

I would be pleased if the Department will authorize an expenditure of $60.00 to purchase material for the construction of a wood shed for the Temiskaming Indian Day School.

At each end of this shed a private toilet would be placed, one for the boys and one for the girls because the ones in use at the present time are not convenient and cannot be kept in good condition.

The labour would be done by Indians who are getting relief. It is absolutely necessary to have a large wood shed because we have to make a provision of stove wood for a part of next winter because the wood is at a long distance now and there is no summer road to go after it.

Your obedient servant

A.F. MacKenzie Esq.
Secretary,

Notre Dame du Nord Que, Aug, 24,1935

Sir

I beg to inform the Department that a new roof is needed to the school house of the Temiskaming band. This was made nearly thirty years ago and is getting in a pretty bad condition. I believed it could be repaired in the few places that it leaks but the shingle is getting so bad that it would not be safe to leave it another year.

I have seen Mr. A. Robert, a contractor who has the contract to put a roof on a school that is being built here at Notre Dame du Nord.

Mr. Robert would be willing to put a roof of sheet iron (tole economie) on the Indian school house for $152.30. This would be put over the shingle, that would be according to Mr. Robert a protection for the sheet iron.

Much of this sheet iron is used around here for roofing and gives good satisfaction. I would be pleased to know if the Department will give authority to this expenditure.

Your obedient servant

A.F. MacKenzie Esq.
Secretary.
Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Notre Dame du Nord Qué, June 10th 1936

Sir-

I beg to inform the Department that a new roof is needed at the Temiskaming Indian Day School house. This roof was repaired last year but it is again leaking in several places.

Mr. Alphonse Robert offers to put a roof in galvanized economic iron for $152.00 (En tole galvanise economique) The first roof was in shingles but it is very old having been made nearly 30 years ago. It would cost less to have the roof made of shingles again but it is hard to get good shingles around here. Most of the people are now making use of galvanized iron. Kindly advise me.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent

A.F. MacKenzie Esq.
Secretary.
Dept. of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.
Ottawa, June 15th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, the Department considers that it would not be advisable to place a galvanized iron roof on the Temiskaming Indian Day School.

Please let me know what it would cost to shingle the roof of this building. You should state the cost of the material and labour. Can Indian labour be secured or will it be necessary to engage a white carpenter? On receipt of your reply, definite instructions will be issued to you.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary

Memorandum:

Mr. MacInnes.

Schools.

I visited the Timiskaming Indian Day School on the 22nd instant.

The school buildings are in good condition, and well kept.

The walls of the classroom are badly in need of paint. $10.00 would cover material and labour. Indians are available to do the painting.

A teacher's desk should be provided. An old, dilapidated table is in use.

Two pieces of blackboard, 10' 4" each, with frame and chalk trough are needed to replace the old ones which are unfit for use.

Some parents complain that the teacher, Sister St. John, spends too much time teaching religious subjects and not enough on secular instruction. Her timetable shows the period of religious instruction to be from 1:15 to 1:45 p.m. She states this is not exceeded.

Average attendance is very good. The pupils are tidy, look healthy, and well cared for. Cod liver oil was given daily in the classroom from October to May.

In her September, 1936, requisition for school supplies, the teacher asked for some construction paper for classroom work. She has not received this and would like to have it supplied for the fall term.

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

The goods covered by the attached invoice were received by the Railroad Company as having been received by them in good condition and properly packed. Any parts broken by the Railroad Company will be duplicated free of charge by us on the following conditions only:

First—The consignee must not give the Railroad Company a clear receipt for the complete shipment if there is any shortage, breakage or damage of any kind. In the event there is any shortage, or if any part of the shipment is damaged, the consignee can give a receipt for the goods if the railroad agent will make a notation on the freight bill indicating the amount of the shortage or the extent and the nature of the damage. This freight bill must be mailed to us.

If the breakage or damage is concealed and not discovered until the goods are unpacked, notify the Agent of the Railroad Company by letter or telephone to call immediately and examine the shipment. The carrier is equally responsible for "Concealed Damage" as for visible damage and when notified as suggested it places the burden of proof upon the carrier. When you have given the Railroad Company notice in the manner suggested, mail us your bill of lading and paid freight bill.

Second—When there is shortage, breakage or damage in an express shipment, request your Express Agent to furnish you receipt showing the condition in which the shipment was delivered to you.

Third—When you report shortage or breakage to us, enumerate fully and describe clearly the parts you desire replaced. In ordering standards for School Desks specify size and whether right or left, which is always determined as you sit at the desk. It is well to supplement your order by mentioning the pattern mark, as will find on the inside of several styles of desks; be sure to specify the style for which the parts are desired, particularly if wooden parts are being ordered. Care in making your order clear and complete will permit us to give you immediate service.

Fourth—All claims for shortage, breakage or damage must be made within Thirty Days and you must provide us with the necessary papers to enable us to file claim against the Railroad or Express Company, as explained in Paragraphs No. 1 and No. 2. Otherwise claim will not be allowed.

STORAGE

The desks manufactured under this contract were constructed from thoroughly air seasoned and properly kiln-dried material and were in perfect condition when shipment left our factory. This does not mean that parts will remain perfect regardless of local atmospheric conditions. Under no condition store this furniture even temporarily in a damp room or basement nor in a partly completed structure where building material, such as plaster, calcimine, paint, etc., may be thrown over the crates. Store in a dry, well ventilated room of normal uniform temperature. The crates containing woods should rest on their ends and all crates and boxes be elevated above floor a few inches to allow free air circulation under and around them.

CLEANING AND POLISHING

Do not attempt to clean or polish the woodwork with linseed oil, turpentine, undiluted benzine, gasoline, alcohol, or anything of that kind. These materials are varnish solvents which soften the varnish and spoil the finish; nor do we recommend any one of the many furniture polishes on the market. The following is a very good cleaner and polish, the constituents of which can usually be obtained in any paint or drug store for a few cents:

Rubbing Oil.
8 parts BOILING WATER.
1 part Benzine.
Mix thoroughly before using.

Moisten a rag with this solution, apply sparingly to the surface and immediately rub dry with a clean dry cloth. Cheesecloth is recommended. The most effective result is obtained through the rubbing, not through excessive use of the solution.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR J. THIBAULT
dated July 8, 1942.

Timiskaming School

The Sister in charge complained about frequent absences of children, whose parents are often keeping them home on the least pretext, such as gardening, hauling wood, etc.; as we have no constable on the Reserve or truant officer, I told her that she should report to Agent about the most frequent ones and it is expected that Agent should try to stop such unnecessary absences. The children are clean and neat in appearance. Due to army clothing being received, the teacher has, more than ever, tried to show the pupils how to make good use of all those things by making them over. No sewing machine is available except an old one which was borrowed two or three times from an Indian family. I recommend that one sewing machine be supplied to the teacher and kept in teacher's quarters, so that instructions can be given in making over old clothing received, to pupils and parents.

November 12, 1946.

H.F. Neary, Superintendent, Welfare & Training.

Acknowledging your letter of November 4th, instant, I must tell you that the Notre Dame du Nord Reserve School is really in a bad condition.

It is a wooden house built 50 years ago at least and is dislocating everywhere. Although they keep the fire burning, it is very uncomfortable for the children and the teacher. Moreover, it is much too narrow and I do not think we could use it as school room next winter.

I did not report on it lately because Mr. Thibault, former inspector of reserves, for the Province of Quebec, had told me that the Department was aware of the present conditions and that it was first on the list to be reconstructed after the war.

Robert Lamorte - Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 20, 1946.

Dear Sir:

We have received your report of October 26 concerning the Temiskaming Indian Day School. We immediately wrote Mr. Indian Agent Lamothe with respect to this situation and have received a report from him on this school. It is quite evident that we will have to plan for a new building.

Unfortunately, Mr. Doucet is in Northern Saskatchewan, inspecting our schools there at the present time. However, we hope to have Mr. Morris, who is the Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies for Quebec and the Maritimes, visit this school in the near future and report upon the whole situation.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary and funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a combined one room Indian day school and teacher's residence in the Temiskaming Indian Agency in the Province of Quebec,

THAT it is essential that educational facilities should be provided for Indian children in the Temiskaming Indian Agency and living quarters for the Indian day school teacher,

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 136, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest.........";

THAT efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors near the said Temiskaming Indian Agency;

THAT a competent constructing firm - P.F. Robert & Dupuis Fils, Notre Dame du Nord, P.Q. - have agreed to undertake the construction of the said building for $13,050.00;

THAT it is considered that the construction of this building is a pressing emergency and it is within the exception of Section 36 above recited.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the construction of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building may be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.

EXCAVATION, DRAINAGE, BACKFILL AND GRADING

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall include all excavation for basement, piers, footings, foundations, catch basin, tile drainage lines, and backfilling for same.

It shall also include cutting away existing banks, prominences etc., to produce graded and terraced areas in the vicinity of the building as required, and fill to produce levels called for on the drawings where finished grade levels are to be higher than existing levels.

It shall further include replacement of top soil as specified herein after grading to lines and levels as shown on the working drawings or as may be directed by the Engineer, has been carried out.

TOP SOIL

From the area around the building, which is to be graded, remove top soil to a depth of 6" and deposit where and as directed by the Engineer.

EXCAVATION

Excavation for all purposes shall conform to the shapes and shall be carried to the levels shown on the working drawings. The sides of all excavations for building shall be sufficiently clear of the outside face of basement or foundation walls to permit erection and stripping of forms and the application of waterproofing, and the laying of weeping tile drains.

Other footing excavations may be cut the next sizes of the footings where soil conditions permit; otherwise the excavation shall be large enough to accommodate the necessary forms.

All footings and foundations shall rest on solid undisturbed soil beds, which shall be at approximately true levels.

Where excavations for walls, piers of footings have been carried, by accident or design, to greater depths than intended, they shall be filled to the required level with concrete, as specified under Concrete Work.

All excavations shall be protected from damage by frost, accident or other cause, and shall be kept dry and free from refuse.

The contractor shall keep all excavations and basements free of water from any source whatsoever, and shall supply all pumps and labour required for this purpose.

All excavated material not required for backfill or for grading shall be moved to another portion of the site, as directed by the Engineer.

ROCK EXCAVATION

Any rock encountered in excavating shall be removed by drilling and wedging as far as possible. If blasting must be resorted to, it shall be done by experienced men, and all precautions shall be taken to ensure the safety of all persons, and to prevent damage to property.

All rough, sloping, loose or soft rock in the bottom of excavations shall be cut away leaving solid beds, and all rock projections at sides of any excavation shall be cut away so that clear space equal to other excavating previously specified is available.
Loose large boulders, which are visible or which may be encountered in excavating, are to be removed by the most convenient method either from the site or to other positions thereon, as directed by the Engineer.

**SHORING**

Supply and place all shoring that may be required to shore up and securely hold all banks or sides of excavations. Maintain and finally dismantle and remove it when work is completed.

**BACKFILLING AT BUILDINGS**

After waterproofing has been completed in accordance with the water-proofing specification and when so directed by the Engineer, fill in against the outside face of the basement walls of the Building with at least 6" of broken stone carefully placed and compacted so that weepers will not be disturbed or damaged. Over the broken stone, and to within 6" of finished grade, fill with well compacted soil. This fill to be well tamped, moistened and consolidated in layers to prevent settlement.

Backfill where necessary in basement around piers, footings and underfloor drainage lines, with excavated material as required to form level bed. Fill to be thoroughly tamped and consolidated to prevent settlement. To the top of footings over this bed spread broken stone as shown on working drawings to form base for concrete floor slab. Stone to be carefully placed and compacted to avoid injury to under-floor drainage lines.

**DRAINAGE**

**Trenches**

Trenches for drainage lines from building as specified for the accommodation of vitrified tile piping shall provide gradients as indicated on drainage details or specified under Plumbing and Drainage. Trenches shall be wide enough to permit workmen to operate.

**Weeping Tile**

Lay a drain of 4" agricultural weeping tile completely around basement foundation walls at proper gradients from bottom of footings as shown on drawings and if the site requires it, upon instructions of the Engineer run branch lines 6' or 8' long running through footings or walls and under basement floor slab where indicated. Where each of these branches passes through footings or walls it shall consist of a section of 4" cast iron pipe of the same length as the width of footing or wall. Care shall be taken that concrete is thoroughly tamped around this cast iron pipe.

Weeping tile shall be laid with 1/8" open joints protected with tar paper strips 6" wide and then covered with not less than 12" of broken stone and gravel, before backfill is placed.

**CONNECT DRAINS TO CATCH BASIN**

Carry all tile drains from foundation footings and basement floor drains and connect to catch basin (See Concrete Specification) in position shown or where directed by the Engineer.
VITRIFIED TILE

Lay an effluent drain of 6" vitrified salt glazed earthenware pipe from catch basin to discharge by gravity flow above grade. If the extent of this drain is not indicated, the contractor shall include in his tender price an amount for installing same to any point selected by the Engineer, within 100' 0" of the building.

Lay 4" similar tile drain, or drains if shown, from catch basin to the proper positions at basement footings and connect same to cast iron basement floor drains.

During laying, each section of vitrified tile shall be solidly supported above bottom of trench and socket-jointed with cement mortar. After jointing, solid beds of soil shall be well packed under pipes.

IRON DRAINS

Run a 4" cast iron pipe drain, or drains if shown, under basement floor from floor drains and any plumbing fixtures to outside of foundation walls under footings and connect to the vitrified tile drains, specified above, running to catch basin.

Provide and install all required Ys, bends, etc., and a C.I. trap and floor strainer to each basement floor outlet.

BACK FILLING

Back filling over all tile and iron drains shall be carefully executed with approved material in a manner to avoid disturbing pipes.

GRADING

Upon completion of the buildings carefully clean up all debris, material, rubbish, etc., from the areas disturbed by building operations and grade up for a distance of 12 feet around the building to levels and lines shown on the various working drawings to the satisfaction of the Engineer.

Where terracing is required, the fill is to be thoroughly rammed and consolidated to prevent settlement.

When all grading has been completed, all graded surfaces and areas are to be covered with topsoil previously removed.

The contractor shall arrange for an adequate supply of fresh water to his concrete mixer and for any other building purpose.
