Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have just returned from my first Missionary trip to Waswanipé and Mistassine in Northern Quebec, and I thought I should write to you while the observations I wish to make are fresh in my mind.

In the first place, I am sorry to say that the school supplies which I ordered when I was in Ottawa more than two months ago had not arrived in time. I wrote to Mr. Phelan, who told me that the printers were behindhand, but that the supplies would be shipped as soon as possible. In the meantime, the teachers are on the spot and would do their best. I think I told you last year that at the two Missions I mentioned there are nearly a thousand Indians, very simple decent people, for whom comparatively little has been done in the educational way.
Dear Mr. Phelan,

I enclose the report of Capt. E. L. Grey who was our missionary preacher at Waswanipi this year. He is very careful and pains-taking man who has set a new standard for us. He has just gone to college for the winter and will go back there next spring.

I want to speak to someone this winter about the need of proper school buildings. I do not think that it should be used as a school indefinitely. It deserves repair and cleaning every year and last year Mr. La Riviere agreed that there should be a proper building.

I hope that you will see that this report goes to the proper quarter.

Yours faithfully,
Robert J. Renison,
Bishop of Moosonee.
MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Proposed Indian Day School at Mistassini

On November 16 the Right Reverend Robert J. Renison, M.A., D.D., Lord Bishop of Moose Cree, visited this office to discuss educational plans in the Diocese of Moose Cree. When informed that the Department was prepared to build an Indian Day School at Waswanipi, he informed us that he felt there was a more urgent need for a permanent day school at Mistassini. Not only are there more Indians at this latter point but they are a more stable group and a day school would have a better chance of success.

As a result of the meeting, the following decisions were reached:

1. That an educational survey be conducted by the Department as soon as possible to decide the location of this school.

2. That His Lordship be informed as soon as the necessary monies have been made available for this purpose.

3. That a decision be deferred until the Spring as to whether the Department will be able to build this school or whether it will be necessary to appeal to the Church of England to have it constructed (as was the case at Fort McPherson).

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
MEMORANDUM FOR FILE

On February 15th, 1947, Mr. Indian Agent Lariviere visited this office and the following proposals were made concerning the provision of Indian Day Schools at Mistassini and Waswasinipi.

The sum of $8,000 has been provided in the 1947-48 estimates for the construction of an Indian Day School at Waswasinipi. In view of the isolated position of both these schools it will not be possible to construct a frame building but it will be necessary to put up log buildings. It is further recommended that in view of the fire hazard which exists in these localities, that separate buildings be constructed for the teacherage and the school.

We therefore plan to proceed as follows with the expenditure of the $8,000 provided in the estimates:

(a) During the following summer logs will be cut by the Indians and hauled into position at Waswasinipi so that a start can be made in the construction of this school in the summer of 1948.

(b) During the following summer logs will be cut by the Indians and hauled into position at Mistassini so that a start can be made in the construction of this school in the summer of 1948.

(c) That a supply of school books be sent in to Mr. Lariviere for use in these schools.
(d) A supply of sporting goods be sent into Mr. Lariviere for use in these schools.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Waswanipi Indian Summer Day School

I have not yet been advised as to who will go in this year, however at this point the question of Kathleen Gull to assist I am sure will come up, shortly after the regular teacher reach Waswanipi, the regular teachers usually have no previous experience with primitive Indians and they don't understand a word of the language.

This girl Kathleen Gull, if she wants to, she can do very good work, this year all these Indians are definitely hard up on account poor trapping lands and mining activities going on in that area, as regard Kathleen it will be as usual, a question of aiding her on DIRECT RELIEF, as much as possible I am trying to avoid this for all Indians, WORKED RELIEF is what we have been aiming at, in her case the only "WORKED RELIEF" possible, would be assisting the teacher.

I feel she should be taken on, as a regular assistant, placed on pay cheques, probably it would encourage her to do better, on regular pay cheques with Indians in this district often it causes lot of trouble, a better arrangement if can be worked out, would be to allow her so much per day and she could take it up through the local trader as required, for clothing and food, they would have no objections to give her also part in cash, this revenue would wipe out in her case needed DIRECT RELIEF.

WASWANIPI. I understand that the school and the teachers' house are already completed. I am sending in Mr. B.J. Stephenson from Trinity College, Toronto, to take charge this summer. He will fly in from Senneterre about June 1st. He will be there until the end of September.

General: I would like to tell you something about the financial of these schools, from our point of view. We are very grateful for the grants to the teachers. In the past, while they have not covered expenses, they have been reasonably adequate. But now, as you know, the cost of living in the north is very high. These students are putting themselves through college. I have found this year that I must guarantee to every man his travelling expenses both ways and $120. a month, as in the case of Mr. Ball, and we must advance their travelling expenses. These men vary in calibre but considering the character of the appointments I would be very glad if you would make the grants as high as possible, otherwise we may not be able to get men for another year and I am sure that until a permanent school is justified the present method is reasonably successful.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I am attending Victoria College in the University of Toronto and I will graduate this year, June 1949. I intend to enroll in Osgood Hall law school this fall.

My experiences as a teacher are various. I was an instructor in the R.C.A.F. for five and a half years and in that time taught air force history and discipline. After my discharge from the air force, my interests led me to the Panama region where I had an opportunity to see at first hand the effects of education on these primitive people. (Darwin Indian)

When I returned to Toronto I enquired about possibilities of teaching among our own Indians. In this way I became affiliated with Frontier College. Last Summer I spent as a teacher with Frontier College at Atikokan Ontario, where I came into contact with the Indians of that area.

I was very pleased when Mr Walsh indicated there might be a spot for me in your summer employment scheme, because it will give me an opportunity to learn what they can teach me and teach them what I know. I am firmly convinced that education is more than half the need of our so called primitive peoples of today.

I am enclosing two letters of reference and my application. I will be glad to hear from you again and I hope my application meets with your approval.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Col. Neary,

In reply to your letter of April 22nd, I am sending you a list of the various Mission Schools and the names of the men whom I would like to place there, with a reason for the choice.

1. Pickle Crow - I regret to say that Mr. Bridle, who is a very able man will be leaving the Central Patricia District about the middle of June. He has done a remarkable work and has united the Indians, under difficult circumstances. He has promised to remain long enough to establish the new man.

I have decided to let you place a man this year, to give his whole time, to the Indian School.

I have written to Mr. Phillip Belyea, P. O. Box 44, Sackville, New Brunswick. He particularly requests, that he should be allowed to go to Pickle Crow, as he knows the district and taught for two years in the Sioux Lookout School.

He will be available from May 11th, to September the 24th.

I forgot to say, that Mr. Bridle is leaving an old car, which he used last year, to transport the children.

2. & 3. Fort Hope & Lansdowne - Mr. Robert Ross of Huron College was at Fort Hope last year and he wants to return. I suggest, that he be allowed to do so. He will be free on May 21st, and will spend three months. You can write to him at Huron College, London, Ontario.

I would like Michael Hankinson, B.A. of St. John's College, Winnipeg to go to Lansdowne. There is a large band of Indians there.
Col. B. F. Neary 2 - April 26th, 1949.

The college closes early and he will be free after the first of May.
His address is,- St. John's College, Broadway & Hargrave, Winnipeg, Manitoba.

4. Collins - For this place, which is on the railroad line, I would suggest Charles Griggs of St. John's College, Winnipeg. He also will be free after the first of May.

I would suggest that these two young men, who are free so early, should be asked to go and report at Nakina, Ontario, from which place, they will fly in. The missionary there, will take care of them.

5. & 6. Mistassini - This is our most important mission and has great possibilities. In one of your letters, you told me that, it might be possible to begin an all-year-round school there, next Fall.

I have William Thompson in mind. I am ordaining him, this Spring, as a deacon, but I want him for the Summer, under the care of an experienced missionary. In the meantime, I would like to send two young men from Trinity College, Toronto, Mr. J. Schaster, B.A. and Mr. Thomas H. Meikle, B.A. They are great friends and served together in the R.C.A.F. For that reason, I have chosen them for this place.

You probably know that they will have to fly in to Mistassini from Rouvraie, Quebec,- The Mount Laurier Aviation Company.

I had hoped, that the school and residence would be finished. I did not see it last year.

The time is short.

I would be very grateful if you would let me know at once, whether this list is satisfactory to you. Some of the men are waiting for definite word, as to when and where they shall go.

In my trip this year, I expect to see every one of them at work.

I expect to leave from Pickle Crow and cover the whole of my district, including Fort George, Whale River and the Belcher Islands, within six weeks.

I suppose you do not want to send anyone with me.

In the past, I have had to give very minute instructions to the various men, as to how to reach their posts. As in most places, they will be using our churches as schools.

We expect these men, to take an interest in the religious life of the community.

Just as soon as I hear from you, I will write to each post, notifying the Hudson's Bay Company or the missionary, when the teachers will arrive.

Yours faithfully,

Robert J. Renison

Dear Colonel Neary,

I have just returned from London and Toronto where I met some of the students who are going north. Schaffter and Meikle met me in Toronto and I have arranged for them to go to Montreal to meet the manager of the Mistassini Hudson's Bay Co. store. I have heard that the old Hudson's Bay house is still habitable and will give them shelter. I have authorized them to purchase whatever is necessary for their trip. Any house equipment the mission will pay for. Other things like personal luxuries they can pay for themselves. I have advanced each of them $100 and have given them an order on the Mont Laurier Aviation Co. at Roberval for return plane fare. They are both keen and competent and will leave early next week. I have also written to Mr. C.H. Brown and Mr. G.W. Thomson who live near Toronto and instructed them to travel to Senneterre. I have given them an order for a plane fare to Waswanapi. So far these are the only men for whom I have advanced money and I am sure that there will be no difficulty. I will either send the bills to you or have them pay me. I would much rather not have to take their cheques myself so that there will be no money transaction between us. If I have made any mistake in assuming that Mr. Brown has accepted you can let me know. I expect to begin my air journey about June 15th at Central Patricia, going down the Albany River, visiting about 6 posts and then around James Bay from Atawapiscut to Whale River and perhaps the Belcher Island then I will go Overland to Mistassini and Waswanapi, ending the journey at Val D'Or. It will be nearly 4,000 miles. I wish you could have sent one of your men with me, or come yourself.

Yours faithfully,
Sgd. Robert Moosonee.

Over.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I wish to inform you that I arrived in Waswanipi, to take over the school, Monday June 13th., having left Toronto the afternoon of Wednesday the 8th.

I have not met Mr. LaRiviere yet, but believe that he will be here on the 27th. Neither the school building nor the teachers' house has been finished yet, but should be so soon, providing some paint, which is on order, arrives.

We are using the church for a temporary school and, since it leaks considerably, especially during heavy rains—and these have occurred daily, except Sunday, since I have been here—we are operating under difficulties. Yesterday afternoon, for instance, I was obliged to give the children a holiday, while this afternoon we were interrupted at three by a heavy shower.

The children retain little of what they have learned in previous years, and I am attempting now to get them back into the knowledge of the alphabet and simple arithmetic. We are short in supplies, using mostly stock left over from previous years. As far as crayons are concerned or teaching aids for the very young children, we have nothing. It may be, however, that some of
much needed articles are included in a shipment now in Amos, awaiting delivery here.

I hope this will elucidate my position.

Yours very truly,

C. H. Brown,
Waswanipi,
C/o. Hudson's Bay Co.,
Senneterre, Que.

(Original on file 478-1)

"WASWANAPI

This is a place that is growing. I found Mr. C.H. Brown of Toronto, who is doing a splendid job. He is an anthropologist and when I arrived there I found that G.W. Thomson of Toronto had not come - for what reason I do not know. I am very glad however because Kathleen Gull, who worked last year, has been acting as his interpreter and kindergarten teacher. I believe that Mr. Lariviere has recommended that she be paid for her services. She is a very attractive girl and very intelligent. Between them they have settled into the new school which is built of logs and is a credit to the department. That is the type of school that I should like to see built at the four Indian Missions on James Bay. The Hudson's Bay Co. are building a new post, there are over 300 Indians there. Mr. Brown had also moved into the teachers new residence. He is the first one to have that privilege. Altogether I was very pleased with Waswanipi and I wish to congratulate Mr. Lariviere on his enterprise.

By the way, I loaned Mr. Brown $50.00 for his travelling expenses which he promptly returned to me on my arrival."

(Sgd.) Robert J. Renison

Ottawa, December 2, 1946.

Waswanipi Indian Day School

Dear Bishop Renison:

Further to our recent conversation, we have checked our files concerning the rental paid for the Anglican Church used as a seasonal day school for Indian education. I find that an amount of $5.00 per month was allowed as rental for each month that this school was in operation. I further discovered that janitor's fees to the amount of $3.00 per academic month were allowed.

The authority for the payment of both these amounts is our letter 44-9-5 of June 21, 1924. Would you please arrange to have accounts to the above amounts forwarded to Mr. Indian Agent Lariviere for next summer's school term.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Right Reverend R. J. Renison, D.D.,
Lord Bishop of Moosonee,
Bishopstope, Porcupine Highway,
Schumacher, Ontario.
The most hopeful thing which I learned from our interview was the promise to build a school and residence at Mistasini this is the largest place and I hope will be merely the beginning. If I can have a definite assurance that this can be undertaken next summer before April 1st, we can undertake plans. I would prefer that the Department erected the buildings but if necessary I would be willing to try to have it done by private contract which could use local labour. The next year we should do the same at Waswanipi. As a matter of fact, we have two buildings there one is the Church which needs restoration as it has been used for a school for twenty five years. There is a residence for the teacher or Missionary which needs an expenditure of $500. to put it in repair. I would be willing to give this building to the Department for a school and summer residence for the Teacher if they would undertake to have it restored. The upstairs could be made into an apartment and the downstairs would make a fairly good school.

(Signed) Robert J. Renison
Bishop of Moosonee

Dear Bishop Renison:

I regret that I was unable to tell you personally of the progress that has been made with regard to schools for Waswanipi and Mistassini. However, I welcomed the opportunity to discuss the situation with Archdeacon Cook and feel certain that he has given you the latest information.

Mr. Lariviere has already arranged with Mr. Sheffield, the manager of the Hudson's Bay Post at Waswanipi, to have the logs for the school cut, piled and peeled. Archdeacon Cook agreed that Mr. Lariviere had made a good point when he recommended that we should not use the logs cut and hauled, free, by the Indians for the purpose of building a church. We certainly do appreciate your offer of these logs but it was felt that there might be some objection on the part of these Indians if the logs were used for building a school and teacher's residence.

As it is, we will be able to cut logs this year, both at Mistassini and Waswanipi, and erect the schools during the next summer. This will give us two schools completed by 1948.

As you are aware, the Indians are hard up in the Waswanipi area particularly and by paying them for getting out the logs, etc., we will provide them with funds to purchase supplies rather than by giving them direct relief.

Archdeacon Cook mentioned the need for a school at Old Factory River and Mr. Conn, our Fur Supervisor, has also

Bishopstope, Porcupine Highway,
Schumacher, Ontario.
discussed the situation with me. I hope to have an opportunity of going into this problem with you on your next trip to Ottawa.

Bishop Renison has two buildings at Wassanipi, one a church and the other a residence for the teacher or missionary. This latter building needs an expenditure of $500.00 to put it in repair. He is willing to give this building to the Department for a school and summer residence for the teacher, if we would undertake to have it restored.

Do you feel that the Department should offer to buy this residence from Bishop Renison? Do you think that we can make any good use of it in your present plans for this area?

Bernard F. Heary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Abitibi Indian Agency
Amos, Que.
March 30th, 1947

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Your No. 35-134 (WT)
March 27th, 1947

In reply, the offer of Bishop Rennison is no doubt very generous, however I do not see that the house in question could be taken over to advantage, built on the Company's land, put up likely by the Indians - labor free - for the Mission, present location poor subject to spring floods, site very bad for flies, condition, it is a large house for our need, new foundation required, very likely also floor, windows and doors in bad shape, the whole building need to be re-inforced, habitable yet but many would not care to do so.

The building has a value, to be pulled apart, the salvaged lumber, considering it is in a remote area, although all hand made, boards are fair to very good and serviceable.

I suggested last year to Rev. Grey, they should pull it part and rebuild, with logs, foundation and walls, they would have sufficient lumber to complete and make a good house, he informed he would suggest it to the Bishop.

On school set up, I feel the teachers must be provided like the nurses with own residence entirely owned by the Department, to put up new school, we have a good site on new clearing, in any event we need protection in case of storms and fires.

This summer the Mission will need the residence offered, for the Company cannot accommodate any one, for any length of time, after the Nursing Station is up, if the Bishop still wish to dispose of their house, we should take over pull apart and put up the teachers residence this year, but to do this it means starting the Indians pulling it down immediately in spring, so we won't run into heavy cost and be left by fall with a house partly taken down, in any event for our use that building for lumber is worth to us $400.00 and we will pay to have it taken down.

I feel Bishop Rennison will be better off, by following my suggestion, rebuild a new house on a new site for the Mission.

Please advise at an early date, so that I can readjust if necessary and get Indians started on it, before our men go in to do the Nursing Station and at the same time they could supervise the pulling apart and salvaging the lumber.

H. Lariviere - Indian Agent.
Ottawa, April 5, 1947.

Waswanipi Indian Day School

Dear Bishop Renison:

In a December letter to me you mentioned a residence for the teacher or missionary at Waswanipi. Your letter states as follows:

"I would be willing to give this building to the Department for a school and summer residence for the teacher if they would undertake to have it restored. The upstairs could be made into an apartment and the downstairs would make a fairly good school."

We wrote to Mr. Lariviere concerning this house and he advises that he would recommend, in view of its age, if you still wish to sell it to the Department, it should be pulled down and the lumber used in rebuilding a new house near the day school site.

Could you please advise me what your plans are concerning this building, now that we are proceeding with the construction of the day school. I believe Mr. Lariviere would want to use the new building as a teacher's residence.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Wwaswanipi - Voucher No. 621
Your letter No. 35-1335 (W.T. 1)
November 25th, 1947

This is as follows:

1.- Rev. Mr. de Pendleton wrote to the Agency, on my return from Mistassini, I found his letter, demanding to hire Kathleen Gull, as a sort of "2nd teacher", I advised him I was not favouring the idea, because Kathleen although when she wanted she was capable, but usually was extremely stubborn and as a whole not dependable and for this year I would not consider it.

2.- On my arrival at Waswanipi, her father Johnny Gull, approached me within a few minutes, as to who was going to pay Kathleen for teaching, I investigated this matter. Rev. de Pendleton had been using her in the school, as "2nd Teacher", during ANNUAL VISIT, I checked further on this, visited the school, every day, I found that Kathleen was doing very well, as regard pay for her work, after "testing for T.B." and so on the usual routine, we found it necessary to send Kathleen for x-ray to La Tuque, she had almost starved to death the winter previous, in any event Johnny Gull, was destitute, his wife is feeble minded, his boy Angus, is an invalid, he looks after his aged mother and father, since Kathleen has returned from Chapleau School, she has been more or less in his hands, "ours" has she is not wanted by the Indians, as a wife, considering she cannot do much on the "trapping end of it". During ANNUAL VISIT, when adjusting this family, I informed Johnny, that aid to Kathleen, instead being direct relief, it would be like for the men, "worked relief" based, worked days, they objected in a way, I informed them when possible a woman like a man if in need of aid, he should work for it, and this year it was the case with Kathleen, they agreed to this.

.............
So Kathleen was seen and told that her aid would be made up with work return, like other Indians working for aid, she accepted that.

3.- I informed Mr. de Pendleton, assuming that Kathleen had not been in need of relief and aid, it would have been impossible to adjust this, except by submitting a request on the Department subject to approval, for it was against all regulations to hire TEACHERS without their approval.

4.- Kathleen in the school, was explaining in Indian to the children, and interpreting for Mr. de Pendleton, she was doing a good job and this Rev. de Pendleton, was also doing a very good job, considering the fact he had put in a lot of time to get the garden up to a point like never before, I felt all concerned would be satisfied and the good work would be maintained.

This allowance, works out to WORKED RELIEF, instead of direct relief, which would have been necessary, had she not done this work. I warned Rev. de Pendleton, Indians don't usually accept that and it is against the established routine to settle "relief matters" along these lines.

Mr. de Pendleton done a good job at Waswanipi, the best since Rev. Rutledge was there years ago, his ways of doing things are inclined to cause difficulties, on minor matters, but he has had no experience with Indians and routine established prior to this year, however he made up a great deal by his good work, not only in the school, gardens and so on.

Teaching school to Indian children and getting them to do garden work, unless they can understand what it is all about, very little good can be expected. Kathleen Gull was used by him to complete and I am satisfied to say, he got results, considering I authorized for Kathleen Gull, on "worked relief" basis.

H. Lariviere - Indian Agent.
December 30th, 1947

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Waswanipi New School

I would appreciate authority to purchase material required to complete this school and make arrangements for men to go in and do this work in spring 1948, as regard men if it can be arranged I would send men to Mistassini last trip in spring on ice, and after they have completed this job, that the same men go in to Waswanipi and complete.

Material required, is mainly windows and doors, also outside sheeting for the school itself, last summer I figured this out, for this building 20 x 40', it would be cheaper to use white asbestos shingles, fireproof and they don't require painting, as regard residence, finish outside exactly like the "Nursing Station" plain peeled logs and painted.

Articles for use in school such as blackboards, desks, and chairs, I presume these could be ordered now for spring delivery, I feel folding chairs would be best for immediate considering freight by air, desks probably we could get these made locally with plywood for shipping purposes being light.

As much as possible I would like to be in a position to arrange in advance for these supplies in view to take advantage of combined trips, for sick Indians if we have to make them from now until break up.

As regard Teachers residence I presume it is the intention to supply them with, an outfit like we do for the nurses, cooking stove, beds, cooking utensils and sundry items strictly needed, a table - likely home made - a few chairs.

H. Lariviere - Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Bishop Benson informed me before I was to come in here that a new residence for the teacher would be provided, also a school building.

But on my arrival here I find that neither have been built. The old mission house has had the majority of its roofing blown off. The door sills have warped and in places there are spaces three inches wide, thus flies etc., cannot be successfully got rid of. The stove upon which cooking is done is useless, the doors have rusted mostly off, likewise the stove-pipes. It can be used for nothing but scrap.

Under these circumstances I feel that it is extremely unfair to ask any sane and human person to try and attempt, and at the same time teach school. The church in which school is taught is rapidly approaching a state of disrepair also.

Thus I write to you at this
time and request advice as to my next course of action. If anything can be done I would also like to submit a request that it be done quickly. Because at the present time the H.B.C. Post can look after me for fifty (50) dollars a month which will leave me no money saved at all. Also the Post cannot guarantee me board and room for any longer than two weeks.

I hope, sir, that I shall hear from you in the near future,

Sincerely Yours,

P. F. Stephenson
(Clerk & Missionary).
To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. of Education

Attached hereto original letter from Mr. B.J. Stephenson Teacher at Waswanipi, I was at Waswanipi, seen Mr. Stephenson, I understand from him, that Bishop Rennison had made him the proposition to go in, with the understanding that the Teacher's residence was ready for occupation also the new school.

I informed Mr. Stephenson, that no doubt the residence and the new school would be completed as soon as possible, but for immediate I could not say when, in any event I would forward his letter on to you, he informed he was writing to Bishop Rennison, but stated that probably he would get no satisfaction as he understood Bishop Rennison this summer was going to England, and just about leaving.

As stated before, the conditions at the "Mission" for a person live in are not acceptable to most persons, refer to his letter.

I will be leaving for Mistassini and Oskelaneo on about June 8th. from Amos, may I suggest that you write direct to Mr. Stephenson mailing copy to this office.

We have two men completing the Nursing Station at Waswanipi, and if the school cannot be completed this year, these men should be ready to come out about end of June, in any event very early in July.

June 9th and 28th, 1948

Waswanipi Indian Summer Day School

Further to telephonic conversation, I now submit bill of material quoted on by Messrs. Simard & Freres Ltd., Amos, Que., subject to immediate acceptance. Item $216.15, for teacher's residence, this to match with other buildings - nursing station. It will be noted, most of this material is finished at shop, to the limit possible, in view to avoid delays at Waswanipi, and where work is more costly, also to overcome cost on air transportation. Item under school $692.46, here again most of it is finished at shop to save on labor at Waswanipi and transportation.

It would be greatly appreciated, that if at all possible, confirmation be wired to this office, and P.O. copy could follow by mail, this will give me enough time to pick up whatever we can at once balance to follow, we will be servicing Waswanipi - Annual Visit - next week. I am most anxious that vacant space on aircrafts be made up with this material, to limit possible, air transportation is the costly end.

There is other items, that we may require, such as some nails, paint to complete teacher's residence, I prefer ordering these later locally, I desire to clean up on this job, anything that be left over on Nursing Stations.

For the schools, we have roofing, oakum already at Waswanipi, also flooring, from last year.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Ind. Agency.

P.S. As regard stove for teacher, hope to get one and ship next week, screens, he should use cheese cloth, will attend to this when in there next week.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. Education
Re: Waswanipi New School & Residence

This job was closed on September 30th, not completed. For 1949, I estimate there is about 30 days work, for 1 man, as follows:

1.- School building: Exterior, a few minor items, about 2 days' work; interior, floor painting, desk for teacher to do, also cupboards for supplies, sink to install, other details, about a day or two.

2.- Residence building: Exterior, painting, interior, cupboard, sink to install, table, partition for rooms, three windows, temporary door to be removed and permanent to put in, painting.

3.- Material, for 1949 probably about $10.00 worth, a few paint brushes, nails, catches.

The school itself can be made ready for occupation very early in spring 1949, residence by middle or late June.

Articles for use in residence, utensils, dishes, etc., to be provided in 1949, this can be shipped in spring 1949.

Buildings at this point will allow teacher to remain there for an extended period, as a matter of fact, both could be used in very cold weather.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Ind. Agency.

P.S. Should back at Amos, latest 21st October.

Pointe Bleue, Aug. 27th, 1918.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

CONDITIONS OF THE INDIANS
at Weymonteihingue,

GENERAL REMARKS.

These Indians, like the others at Manawan and Obidjnan whom I had the occasion to meet, are cruelly intelligent for people who have no knowledge of education. A little school opened for five or six months during the temperate season, would produce excellent results amongst the children of these fine Indians. The future generation would nor longer be the same. It would be necessary to live really twenty years in the midst of the Indians to find the extraordinary results and to truly understand how enlightened is the policy which the Department has followed with regard to education amongst the Indians. It is by education and by education alone that good citizens can be made. It is by inculcating in those of tender age by continued education, highest principles and instructing them in the two supreme principles of good and evil that they will be made men and not otherwise.

I have the honour to be

Sir,
Your obedient servant,
Armand Tessier,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 16, 1918.

Sir,

In reference to that portion of your letter of the 27th of August, last, in regard to the establishment of a school for the Indians at Weymontachingue I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to establish a school for these Indians at the present time, as the funds at its disposal are very limited.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Armand Tessier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, Que.
Maniwaki, Que., 13th February 1925

To D. McLean, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

The Indians of Wemuntashig are desirous to obtain the services of two teachers for next spring; one for classroom activity and the other for field matron's duties in the Indian homes. But they ask for a summer school for the months of June, July, August and September. Their intention too is to learn French language.

I hope, Sir, your Department will comply with that laudable desire and will grant the two teachers to the poor Indians.

Your servant in X

Rev. Joseph Guérard O.M.I.
Ottawa, February 27th, 1925.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, requesting that a summer school be conducted this coming summer at Weymontaching for the benefit of the Indian children at that point.

In reply I beg to say that, after considering this request, the Department regrets that owing to the funds at our disposal being limited it will not be possible at the present time to provide the expenditure required in conducting a school at this point next summer. The last census taken shows that there is only a total of 89 Indians at Weymontaching, and it is, therefore, doubtful if there would be a sufficient number of Indian children available to make the work a success.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Jos. E. Guinard, O.M.I.,
Maniwaki,
Que.

MEMORANDUM:

Schools Branch.

With reference to the request by Rev. Jos. E. Guinard for a summer school at Weymontachi, I beg to say that I consider the Reverend Father's request a reasonable one. These Indians, who are now coming in contact with civilization, have never had any opportunity for education. They are, as yet, quite unfit to conduct their affairs with unscrupulous whites and each year makes the demand for such fitness more evident.

I know the Reverend Guinard personally having come in contact with him as a missionary to the Indians for the past fifteen years. He has laboured hard and asked little or nothing from outside sources. I am quite satisfied that for any grant given he will see that full value is rendered.

I think the figure quoted as to number of Indians (89) is quite wrong. To my knowledge there are over one hundred there.

As regards accommodation, there is a large house on the reserve that, I think, would be available and if the school proves successful after due trial, we could probably buy the building at a reasonable figure.

As so little is spent on these Northern Quebec Indians, I am personally most anxious to see some start made in the way of education and know of no better start than the plan suggested by the Reverend Father.
I will be visiting the reserve this summer and will be pleased to report on the matter at that time if a start has been made. In the meantime I would recommend that Reverend Guinard's request be given favourable consideration and that he be advised to go ahead.

I do not think that school furniture need be provided at this time. A start could be made with temporary equipment, if teachers, books and stationery are provided.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector.

Sir,

Sorry that I did not give you more details on the precedent reports because I was waiting to give them on my last report (Sept report) but as you like to know my activities among the Indians I must tell you that they are a lot better this year than they were years before. I teach them how to keep their houses clean and I make them clean them in the spring when they come home from the bush, and I did not want them to put up tents this summer for the good reason that they have better chance to learn how to keep house when they live in it, of course it saves them work to be outside well I believe it is something worth on the hygienic part.

When they came home in the spring every one of them was sick some in very bad shape, so I had to attend to them every day going in every house trying to help them the best I could, always busy even on Sunday.

Besides they increase on the way of economy made them save their money by telling them to buy just what they want for food and clothes, some of them had money for all summer.
Their potatoes are good from the seed the government send them. I showed them how to cut their seeds and plant them. RE: Inspection of Abitibi Agency - Amos, P.Q.

WEYMONTACHIE

There is a strange feeling existing that we may lose the services of our teachers, unless conditions change, as it is yet the matter of cost to them for feeding visitors, and having to do things which are not part of their duties as school teachers.

There is actually great improvement, specially concerning TB, and, at this time, only one TB case cannot be hospitalized, the woman is expecting child birth.

All Indians have been immunized against smallpox, diphtheria, and typhoid.

There was no school garden this year, many Indians had a garden, with fair result.

Since their health has improved within the last few years, these Indians worked outside more than they used to and earned fair wages, more specially this year. Homes are better kept and cleaner.

However, hunting and trapping is getting harder every-year for this band; trapping grounds are covered with lumber operations and Club owners. Principal trouble is liquor and contacts with sports hunting in the fall.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Bishop Remison visited this office recently and advised that he will soon be in a position to nominate teachers for the seasonal schools at each of the above points.

Ottawa, April 1, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, addressed to Mr. Sutherland of this Department, regarding the appointment of teachers for the Indian summer schools at Manouan, Weymontaching and Obedjiwan.

It is noted that you have re-engaged the same teachers as were employed at these schools last summer, and the Department will approve of their re-engagement, as follows:

Manouan:
Miss Ursule Boredeau ... Teacher,
Miss Philomene Drolet ... Asst. Teacher & Matron.

Weymontaching:
Miss Beatrice Foy ... Teacher,
Miss Wilhelmine ... Asst. Teacher & Matron.

Obedjiwan:
Miss Germaine Cote ... Teacher,
Miss Juliette Lafrance ... Asst. Teacher & Matron.

Salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month will be allowed to the teacher in charge and $65 per month to the assistant teacher and matron, less 10 percent, in each case, during the summer months of 1933.

The teacher at each school should prepare the usual returns showing attendance, days' taught, etc., stating thereon their post office addresses, and forward same to the Department at the end of each month, in order that payment of salary due can be made. The assistant teacher and matron should also prepare a brief statement showing the work performed each month. On the first returns forwarded, the teachers should state definitely the date on which they began duties, and when submitting the final returns they should also state the date upon which the school closed. These summer schools should reopen on the first of June, next, and remain in operation until the end of September, following. I would request that you advise the teachers accordingly and arrange with them to commence duties on or about the date mentioned.

It is hoped there will be a regular attendance of the Indian children and that the teachers will meet with success in the work.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Quebec, P.Q.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from John Peters, Cornwall Island, regarding the educational facilities provided on that reserve. He requests that a new school-house be built near the O. N. Y. Railway station and that the present school-house be moved further east, in order that the children will not have to travel so far going to and coming from school. He says that the most of the children live near the west and east ends of the island, and it is too far during the cold weather for them to walk to the present school, and as a consequence many of the children stay home on account of the distance they have to go.

In a letter dated the 10th of March, 1915, you brought this matter to the attention of the Department, and in reply you were informed that, as you intended shortly thereafter to visit the Department, this matter would be discussed with you then.

There is no record on file as to your further views on the matter, and I have now to request you be good enough to look into this question and give your views fully regarding the need of another school located at the west end of the island and the present school nearer the east end. You should state number of Indian children of school age residing at west ends respectfully.

Yours obediently,

F. H. Taillon, Esq.,

Sir,

Sir:

As you are aware, it is the intention of the Department to erect a new day school building on the Cornwall Island Reserve, at either the eastern or western end of the island. Only one new building will be erected this year, and this matter was discussed with you during a visit made by you to the Department. The matter of deciding on which end of the island this school should be erected was left to you.

We are now ready to proceed with the plans, and it will be necessary to definitely decide where this building is to be erected and to secure the necessary site. I shall, therefore, be pleased if you will state at which end of the island you would advise the first school to be built. If possible, you should also secure at least an acre of ground which should be level and well drained. You will be good enough to arrange for the obtaining of the site as soon as possible, and give us particulars regarding the same. If it is necessary to purchase the ground, it should be secured as cheaply as possible and should be as central to the needs of the locality as can be obtained.

I shall be glad if you will state the number of pupils for which the school should be built and also whether you would advise that living quarters for a teacher be included, either in the building or in an annex thereto. An early reply will be appreciated.

Sir,

I am of the opinion that the delay in erecting the school will not have any ill effect, although some of the radicals may claim the glory of hindering the work; yet I believe if you will be in a position to erect both schools next year that it will prove more effective to wait until then, at any rate a school could not be ready for use before some time after the new year, so in reality we will not be at so much inconvenience for this term.

Schools:

The attendance at the Agency schools during December was low, due to the severe weather and storms. Cod Liver Oil was delivered to the schools in late November and teachers instructed to see that the children received the same. During December there was a considerable falling off in the attendance of Indian pupils to the Shannonville and Milltown white schools, due to inclement weather and sickness.

It will be noted in some cases very low average for December. This is due to the flu epidemic mostly. In general it can be said that attendance at the various schools has maintained a high level. Such a high percentage is particularly noteworthy at the Chetlain school where it was difficult to get the boys to school. The reverse is now the case as far as the boys are concerned. With the exception of the Cornwall Island East school no manual training is carried on. The village boys get the benefit of some training along this line when such is possible with the time at the disposal of the local constable. With only one man now stationed here less time can be devoted to such work among the boys. Due to the poor freezing of the St. Lawrence this winter it has not been possible during December to get to St. Regis Island School. Too conditions are such that it is not safe to walk nor can a boat be used. Only emergency trips are made by the Indian residents of the island.

In general the children on the whole appear to be well-behaved and industrious. There is very little incentive for those children in our Quebec schools to devote much energy to studies after they reach the age of 15 as the prospect of being able to attend a high school is no better than in past years. The hard period to keep those children at school is between the age of 15 and 16. The boys in particular just won't exert themselves too much after 15. This situation is most unfortunate as they have just reached a point in life when they should be capable of absorbing some knowledge. I feel though that if we could give them the kind of training they would like at this period we would be well repaid and would not have any attendance problem on our hands to contend with.

Acting on the complaint of Angus Lazore, Indian of Cornwall Island Reserve, Constable Brown, R.C.M.P., and the undersigned visited Cornwall Island East School on the 7th instant to discuss the matter with the teacher, Mr. Ryan. It was alleged by Mr. Lazore that the teacher had used his fists to punish his daughter, Evelyn Lazore.

I might say that very little was accomplished through our investigation apart from the fact that the pupil stuck her tongue out at the teacher. We endeavoured to leave the impression with Mr. Ryan that corporal punishment should be administered only when necessary and then only in accordance with the law. I might add there does not appear to be very much order in the class and while there is a marked improvement over a few months ago, the teacher concerned is too nervous a type to deal with our Indians. He appears to be eager enough to learn the various angles connected with the teaching profession and he is apparently working hard enough but I fear he is losing prestige amongst the people.

MEMORANDUM TO FILE:

JORNWALL ISLAND EAST INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

At ten o'clock today Mr. Bonnah phoned me from St. Regis to advise that he had had a report from Major Pendegast, R.C.A.M.A., with regard to the above mentioned teacher. Apparently Mr. Ryan had had some sort of seizure in a street car at Cornwall upon which Major Pendegast was riding.

I contacted Major Pendegast (Government phone 6732) and he told me the following story:

"That on Saturday at approximately noon he was talking with an Indian on the St. Regis Reserve when a stranger came up to him and asked a series of disjointed and queer questions. The Indian said; "That man's crazy" and then told the Major that the stranger was Mr. Ryan, the teacher at the Cornwall Island East School. Major Pendegast then left the Indian and started to walk towards the street car. He noticed Mr. Ryan ahead of him jumping in a series of gazelle-like leaps towards the car. On the car Mr. Ryan sat by himself and after a short interval began shaking his head with his fists and rocking back and forth. He kept tearing at his clothes and muttering to himself. Although he was creating a considerable disturbance, no one on the street car made any effort to interfere with him, as he seemed rather dangerous.

Major Pendegast then saw him leave the car and bound into the post office in a somewhat similar manner, to that in which he had entered the street car."

Major Pendegast, while not wishing to appear a busybody, gave this statement voluntarily and recommended that action be taken to have Mr. Ryan medically examined. Major Pendegast is willing to submit a signed statement concerning the above incident, if such is necessary.
May 6, 1948.
